definition: a visible mass of particles of condensed vapor (such as water or ice) suspended in the atmosphere of a planet (such as the earth) or moon
something resembling or suggesting a cloud: such as

a light filmy, puffy, or billowy mass seeming to float in the air                                      
             
             a cloud of blond hair
a usually visible mass of minute particles suspended in the air or a gas
an aggregation of usually obscuring matter especially in interstellar space
an aggregate of charged particles (such as electrons)

a great crowd or multitude : swarm                                      
             
             clouds of mosquitoes

something that has a dark, lowering, or threatening aspect                                      
             
             clouds of war

something that obscures or blemishes                                      
             
             a cloud of ambiguity
a dark or opaque vein or spot (as in marble or a precious stone)

the computers and connections that support cloud computing                                      
             
             storing files in the cloud

to grow cloudy                                      
                
                  —usually used with over or up          clouded over before the storm

to become troubled, apprehensive, or distressed in appearance                                      
             
             her face clouded with worry

to become blurry, dubious, or ominous                                      
                
                  —often used with over          the outlook is clouding over
to billow up in the form of a cloud
to envelop or hide with or as if with a cloud

to make opaque especially by condensation of moisture                                      
             
             steam clouded the windows

to make murky especially with smoke or mist                                      
             
             smoke clouded the sky

to make unclear or confused                                      
             
             cloud the issue

taint, sully                                      
             
             a clouded reputation

to cast gloom over                                      
             
             cloud prospects for success
a white or gray mass in the sky that is made of many very small drops of water
a large amount of smoke, dust, etc., that hangs in the air
a large group of things (such as insects) that move together through the air
to confuse (a person's mind or judgment)
to make (something, such as an issue or situation) difficult to understand
to affect (something) in a bad way
a visible mass of tiny bits of water or ice hanging in the air usually high above the earth

a visible mass of small particles in the air                                      
             
             a cloud of dust

a large number of things that move together in a group                                      
             
             a cloud of mosquitoes

an overwhelming feeling                                      
             
             The news cast a cloud of gloom.
the computers and connections that support cloud computing

to make or become cloudy                                      
             
             The sky clouded up.

to have a bad effect on                                      
             
             Involvement in the crime clouded his future.

to make confused                                      
             
             Doubts clouded her judgment.
in: a cloud of blond hair
a ship under a cloud of sail
clouds of mosquitoes
clouds of war
a cloud of suspicion
a cloud of ambiguity
storing files in the cloud
cloud storage/backup
cloud software
clouded over before the storm
her face clouded with worry
the outlook is clouding over
steam clouded the windows
smoke clouded the sky
cloud the issue
a clouded reputation
cloud prospects for success
cloudlike swirls
cloudlike chocolate mousse
The sun is shining and there's not a cloud in the sky.
flying high above the clouds
It stopped raining and the sun poked through the clouds.
a cloud of cigarette smoke
The team has been under a cloud since its members were caught cheating.
There's a cloud of controversy  hanging over the election.
greed clouding the minds of men
These new ideas only cloud the issue further.
The final years of her life were clouded by illness.
a cloud of dust
a cloud of mosquitoes
The news cast a cloud of gloom.
The sky clouded up.
Involvement in the crime clouded his future.
Doubts clouded her judgment.

definition: a white or grey mass of very small drops of water in the sky
Adjectives
Verbs
a large amount of smoke, dust, steam etc in the air
any large mass in the sky that looks like a cloud
something unpleasant that spoils an activity, event, or situation
to feel depressed or unhappy
in: A few white clouds drifted across the sky.
There’s more cloud than yesterday.
a dust cloud
cloud of: a huge cloud of black smoke
A thick cloud of flies buzzed around us.
a cloud of anxiety/misery/uncertainty
be/cast a cloud over something: Violent protests cast a cloud over the president’s visit.
a cloud on the horizon  (=something that is likely to spoil a situation): The only cloud on the horizon is the possibility of a hostile takeover.
the cloud
every cloud has a silver lining
on cloud nine
under a cloud

definition: a grey or white mass in the sky, made up of very small floating drops of water:
a mass of something such as dust or smoke that looks like a cloud:
a computer network where files and programs can be stored, especially the internet:
If something transparent clouds, or if something clouds it, it becomes difficult to see through.
to make someone confused, or make something more difficult to understand:
a white or gray mass of very small drops of water or ice that float in the sky:
A cloud is also a mass of something, such as dust or smoke, that moves together:
A cloud is also something which causes sadness or fear:
to fill with clouds or with something that looks like a cloud:
If something clouds a situation or feeling, it makes it less clear:
in: Do you think those are rain clouds on the horizon?

Dark clouds massed on the horizon.
There was so much cloud, we couldn't see anything.

The initial cloud of tear gas had hardly cleared before shots were fired.

Smoke clouded the sky.
The fact that Jack was an old friend clouded her judgment.
